content.rendered:
Check Your Maryland Voter Registration

One of the easiest ways to protect your vote is to make sure your voter registration is accurate and up to date. A quick review helps ensure you receive the correct ballot, avoid Election Day issues, and keep Maryland’s voter rolls accurate.


Use the official Maryland voter lookup tool to confirm your name, address, party affiliation, polling place, and voter status.

👉 Check Your Registration Here

If anything needs updating, the portal will guide you through the steps.

Stay Engaged. Stay Informed. Stay Registered.

 

 

At SecureTheVoteMD, we believe that election integrity begins with each individual voter.
Checking your own registration is a small step that helps protect Maryland’s elections in a big way.

 

Encourage your family, friends, and neighbors to check theirs too—every informed voter strengthens our state.

Report Card

This report card provides citizens with scientifically developed data highlighting inaccuracies in the Maryland Voter Registration Database and voting processes. It objectively demonstrates that the Maryland Board of Elections has failed to effectively manage the electoral process and its associated systems. This “failing” grade serves as a call to action for Maryland citizens to visit SecuretheVoteMD.com and sign our petition, which will be presented to state legislators to demand reforms in the election process. Confidence in our elections can only be restored when the voting process accurately represents the will of the people.

Maryland NVRA Violations

Maryland Voter Roll Violations & Over-Registration Warning

SecureTheVoteMD.com | 2025 Analysis

 

Under the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), states are required to maintain accurate and up-to-date voter registration lists. Yet, data from Maryland shows clear violations, with inflated rolls and active registrants exceeding the eligible population in some counties.

 

NVRA Violations in Maryland – Summary by County

The following data highlights apparent violations of the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA) across Maryland counties. Key issues include duplicate registrations, deceased individuals remaining on the rolls, and voters registered as over 115 years old. The law also requires regular maintenance of voter rolls, including removal of individuals who have moved out of the state. This summary underscores the urgent need for greater oversight and compliance with voter list maintenance provisions.

content.rendered:
Become an Election Judge in 2026

SecureTheVoteMD is seeking community members to serve as election judges and help ensure fair, accessible, and secure elections. No prior experience is required—comprehensive training is provided.

Election judges are responsible for:

  • Setting up and closing polling places
  • Checking in and assisting voters
  • Overseeing election procedures

Minimum requirements:

  • Registered voter in Maryland
  • Able to read, write, and speak English
  • Physically and mentally able to work a 15-hour day
  • Willing to work outside your home precinct
  • Able to sit or stand for long periods

Not eligible: Candidates, elected officials, political party central committee members, or campaign officers (chair, manager, or treasurer).

Preferred but not required:

  • Computer familiarity
  • Bilingual skills (highly encouraged)
  • Ability to lift 10–25 lbs (for certain roles)

If you are ready to serve your community and safeguard the democratic process, please complete the [Election Judge Interest Form] below.

content.rendered:
Introduction to the Maryland Signature Verification Legislation

The proposed Signature Verification bill aims to enhance the integrity and public trust in Maryland’s absentee voting system by requiring a verified voter signature—and, in most cases, a witness signature—on all returned absentee ballots. This legislation ensures that only legally cast ballots are counted by mandating local boards of elections to confirm that each absentee ballot was submitted by the registered voter, using signature comparison against official registration records. In a time when absentee and mail-in voting are increasingly common, implementing this safeguard is essential to deterring fraud, preventing unauthorized voting, and preserving the accuracy of election results. Signature verification is already a widely accepted best practice in many states, balancing accessibility with security while maintaining consistency across jurisdictions. Currently, Maryland lacks a uniform standard for signature verification, and this legislation seeks to correct that gap—bringing the state in line with proven national election security practices and reinforcing the legitimacy of every vote counted.

 

Why signature verification is essential to accurate and trustworthy elections:

  • Ensures Election Integrity: Signature verification provides a layer of security to confirm that the absentee ballot was cast by the registered voter, helping prevent fraud and unauthorized voting.
  • Promotes Voter Confidence: Voters are more likely to trust the electoral process when safeguards like signature verification are in place to ensure the authenticity of ballots.
  • Balances Accessibility and Security: While absentee voting expands access, verifying signatures ensures that increased accessibility does not compromise the integrity of the election.
  • Aligns with Best Practices: Signature verification is a standard practice in many states and is a proven method for safeguarding mail-in and absentee voting systems.
  • Protects Against Misuse: By requiring a signature match, the process deters attempts to tamper with or forge absentee ballots.
  • Supports Accurate Election Outcomes: Verifying signatures reduces the risk of counting invalid ballots, ensuring that only legally cast votes are included in the final tally.
  • Maintains Uniform Standards: Establishing clear guidelines for signature verification provides consistency in election administration across jurisdictions.

 

A BILL ENTITLED
AN ACT concerning
Election Law – Absentee Ballots – Signature Requirements and Verification

 

FOR the purpose of prohibiting a local board of elections from removing an absentee ballot from a return envelope or ballot/return envelope or counting the ballot unless the return envelope or ballot/return envelope is signed by the voter and, except under certain circumstances, a witness, and requiring the local board to verify the voter’s signature; and generally relating to absentee ballots.

 

BY repealing and reenacting, with amendments,
Article – Election Law
Section 9–303 and 9–310(a)(5) and (c)
Annotated Code of Maryland
(2022 Replacement Volume and 2023 Supplement)

 

BY adding to
Article – Election Law
Section 9–310.1
Annotated Code of Maryland
(2022 Replacement Volume and 2023 Supplement)

 

SECTION 1. BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF MARYLAND,
That the Laws of Maryland read as follows:

 

Article – Election Law

9–303.
(a) The State Board shall establish guidelines for the administration of absentee voting by the local boards.

(b) The guidelines shall provide for:

  1. the application process;
  2. late application for absentee ballots;
  3. ballot security, including storage of returned ballots;
  4. determining timeliness of receipt of applications and ballots, including applications and ballots for overseas voters;
  5. the canvass process;
  6. notice of the canvass to candidates, political parties, campaign organizations, news media, and the general public;
  7. observers of the process;
  8. review of voted ballots and envelopes for compliance with the law and for machine tabulation acceptability;
  9. standards for disallowance of ballots during the canvass;
  10. storage and retention of ballots following canvass and certification;
  11. the permanent absentee ballot list; and
  12. verification of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes.

 

(c) The State Board shall:

  1. in consultation with the local boards, assess the guidelines before each primary election; and
  2. revise the guidelines if indicated.

 

9–310.
(a)(5) When voted and returned to the local board, an absentee ballot shall be enclosed in a ballot envelope or ballot/return envelope, on which has been printed oaths prescribed by the State Board.

 

(c) If an absentee ballot is sent by the Internet or facsimile transmission, the local board shall provide the voter with an envelope template, the oaths prescribed by the State Board, and instructions for marking and returning the absentee ballot.

 

9–310.1.

(a) Definitions.
In this section, “uniformed services” has the meaning stated in 10 U.S.C. § 101.

 

(b) Conditions for Opening or Counting Ballots.
A local board may not remove an absentee ballot from the return envelope or ballot/return envelope or count the ballot unless:

  1. The return envelope or ballot/return envelope is signed by:
    The voter to whom the ballot was issued; and
    ii. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a witness other than the voter to whom the ballot was issued; and
  2. The voter’s signature is verified as provided in subsection (d) of this section.

 

(c) Witness Signature Exemption.
The witness signature requirement under subsection (b)(1)(ii) of this section does not apply to an absentee ballot that is voted and returned by:

  1. An active-duty member of the uniformed services who is serving overseas; or
  2. The spouse or dependent of an active-duty member of the uniformed services who is serving overseas if the spouse or dependent lives overseas.

 

(d) Signature Verification.
Each local board shall verify the signature of the voter on the return envelope or ballot/return envelope by comparing the signature with the voter’s registration record in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Board.

content.rendered:
Introduction to the Maryland Voter ID Bill

The proposed Voter ID bill is a vital step toward ensuring the integrity, security, and transparency of Maryland’s elections. By requiring all in-person voters to present a valid photo identification, this legislation strengthens election security, helps prevent voter fraud, and reinforces public confidence in the democratic process. Voter ID laws are a common-sense safeguard supported by most Americans and reflect standard practices used in everyday life—from cashing a check to boarding a plane. Notably, Maryland is one of only 14 states that currently do not require photo identification to vote, leaving our elections more vulnerable to inconsistencies and errors. This bill addresses those concerns while also ensuring accessibility by requiring the State Board of Elections to provide free voter photo identification cards to any registered voter upon request. With clear guidelines, compassionate exceptions, and practical implementation strategies, this proposal ensures fair and equal voting standards across the state while protecting every eligible citizen’s right to vote.

 

Why voter identification requirement is essential to accurate and trustworthy elections:

 

  • Enhances Election Security: Requiring photo identification helps ensure that only eligible voters cast ballots, reducing the potential for voter impersonation and fraud.
  • Promotes Public Confidence: Voters are more likely to trust the integrity of the electoral process when measures like photo ID requirements are in place.
  • Widely Accessible IDs: Photo IDs are commonly used in daily life for activities like banking, travel, and accessing government services, making compliance straightforward for most voters.
  • Safeguards Against Errors: Photo ID verification can help reduce clerical or administrative errors in identifying voters at polling places.
  • Consistent Voter Identification: Establishing a uniform requirement ensures equal standards across all voting locations, preventing discrepancies.
  • Supports Accurate Outcomes: By verifying identity, photo ID requirements help ensure that only legitimate votes are counted, protecting the integrity of election results.
  • Broad Public Support: Polls consistently show that most Americans, across political affiliations, support voter ID laws as a common-sense measure. Maryland is one of only 14 states not to require photo identification to vote.

 

OVERVIEW:

The below text outlines the requirements for photo identification to vote in person in Maryland including a new requirement for the State Board of Elections to provide, upon request, a Voter Photo Identification Card.

​

It specifies acceptable forms of ID, verification processes, provisional ballot procedures, and exceptions for those unable to provide ID due to religious objections, reasonable impediments, or natural disasters.

​

It also details the review process for exceptions and the purpose of the ID requirement.

 

Finally, the selected text outlines the procedures and regulations for issuing voter photo identification cards in accordance with Maryland Election Law § 10-315.

 

Photo Identification Required to Vote

  • Voters must present a valid photo ID to vote in person.
  • Acceptable IDs include MD driver’s license, special ID cards, US passport, MD voter photo ID, student and employee IDs, out-of-state driver’s licenses (if registered within 90 days of the election), military IDs, Veterans ID cards, tribal enrollment cards, and government-issued IDs for public assistance programs.
  • Expired IDs are acceptable for voters aged 65 or older if the ID was valid on their 65th birthday.

 

Verification of Photo Identification

  • Precinct officials will compare the photo on the ID with the person presenting to vote.
  • If there is a dispute, a challenge will be conducted, and the voter can vote unless all election judges unanimously agree the ID does not resemble the voter.

​

Provisional Ballot Required Without Photo Identification

  • Voters without acceptable ID can cast a provisional ballot, which will be counted if they present an acceptable ID to the county board of elections by the deadline.
  • Voters will receive an information sheet on acceptable IDs and the deadline for submission.

 

Exceptions

  • Religious Objection: Voters with religious objections to being photographed can complete an affidavit and cast a provisional ballot.
  • Reasonable Impediment: Voters with reasonable impediments preventing them from obtaining an ID can complete an affidavit and a reasonable impediment declaration form to cast a provisional ballot.
  • Natural Disaster: Voters affected by a natural disaster within 100 days before the election can complete an affidavit and cast a provisional ballot.

 

Reasonable Impediment Declaration Form

  • The form includes options for lack of transportation, disability or illness, lack of required documents, work schedule, family responsibilities, lost or stolen ID, ID applied for but not yet received, and other reasonable impediments.

 

County Board Review of Exceptions

  • The county board will validate provisional ballots cast due to inability to provide ID if the required affidavit is submitted, unless there are grounds to believe the affidavit is false.

 

Purpose

  • The purpose of the ID requirement is to confirm the voter’s identity, not their residence, which is determined by other means.
  • 10-315. Requirement for Photo Identification to Vote in Person

 

(a) Photo Identification Required to Vote.
When a registered voter presents to vote in person, the voter shall produce any of the following forms of identification that contain a photograph of the voter:

 

(1) Any of the following that is valid and unexpired, or has been expired for one year or less:
a. A Maryland driver’s license.
b. A special identification card for non-drivers issued by the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA).
c. A United States passport.
d. A Maryland voter photo identification card issued by the State Board of Elections.
e. A student identification card issued by a college or university in Maryland, provided the card is issued in accordance with the rules established by the State Board of Elections.
f. An employee identification card issued by a state or local government entity in Maryland.
g. A driver’s license or special identification card for non-drivers issued by another state, the District of Columbia, or a United States territory, but only if the voter registered within 90 days of the election.

 

(2) Any of the following forms of identification, regardless of whether the identification contains an expiration date:
a. A military identification card issued by the United States government.
b. A Veterans Identification Card issued by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs.
c. A tribal enrollment card issued by a federally or state-recognized tribe.
d. An identification card issued by a federal or Maryland state agency for a government program of public assistance.

 

(3) Any expired form of identification listed in this subsection, if presented by a registered voter who is 65 years or older, provided that the identification was valid on the voter’s sixty-fifth birthday.

 

(b) Verification of Photo Identification.
Precinct officials shall compare the photograph on the identification with the individual presenting to vote. If the officials dispute the voter’s identity based on the photograph, a challenge shall be conducted in accordance with Maryland Election Law § 10-312. A voter shall be allowed to vote unless election judges unanimously agree that the photo identification does not reasonably resemble the voter.

 

(c) Provisional Ballot Without Photo Identification.
If a voter cannot produce photo identification as required, they may cast a provisional ballot. The ballot will be counted if the voter presents acceptable photo identification to the local board of elections by the close of business on the day before the canvass of provisional ballots. The State Board of Elections shall provide the voter with information on deadlines and acceptable forms of identification.

 

(d) Exceptions.

(1) Religious Objection.
If a voter cannot provide photo identification due to a religious objection to being photographed, they may complete an affidavit under penalty of perjury at the voting location affirming their identity and religious objection. Upon completion of the affidavit, the voter may cast a provisional ballot.

 

(2) Reasonable Impediment.
If a voter cannot provide photo identification due to a reasonable impediment, they may complete an affidavit under penalty of perjury and a reasonable impediment declaration form, affirming their identity and the nature of the impediment. Acceptable impediments include:
a. Lack of transportation.
b. Disability or illness.
c. Lack of necessary documents.
d. Work schedule.
e. Family responsibilities.
f. Lost or stolen identification.
g. Identification applied for but not yet received.
h. Other impediments as described by the voter.

 

(3) Natural Disaster.
A voter affected by a natural disaster declared by the President of the United States or the Governor of Maryland within 100 days of the election may complete an affidavit to cast a provisional ballot.

 

(e) County Board Review.
If the local board of elections determines that a provisional ballot was cast due to the lack of photo identification and the required affidavit was completed, the ballot shall be considered valid unless the board has reason to believe the affidavit is false.

 

(f) Purpose.
The purpose of photo identification is to confirm that the individual presenting to vote is the registered voter on the voter rolls. The address on the identification is not determinative of residence for voting purposes. Residency for voting is determined pursuant to Maryland Election Law § 3-202.

 

In addition, we believe in order to strengthen this bill and dispel any resistance to the voter id requirement based on access to proper identification, we encourage an additional required duty of the State Board of Elections to provide, upon request, a voter photo identification card to all registered voters.

 

Here’s our best attempt at the language we might use to add the requirement of the BOEs to issue, upon request, Voter Photo Identification Cards to all voters.

    • § 3-205. Voter Photo Identification Cards

 

(a) Issuance of Voter Photo Identification Cards.
The local boards of elections in each county, in accordance with this section, shall issue voter photo identification cards upon request to registered voters without charge. The voter photo identification cards shall:

    1. Contain a photograph of the registered voter, the name of the registered voter, and the voter registration number of the registered voter.
    1. Be used solely for voting purposes.
    1. Expire 10 years from the date of issuance.

The expiration of a voter photo identification card does not affect the validity of the voter’s registration status, nor shall a voter’s registration be rendered inactive solely due to the expiration of the voter photo identification card.

 

(b) Equipment for Voter Photo Identification Cards.
The Maryland State Board of Elections shall provide the necessary equipment for printing voter photo identification cards to the local boards of elections. The local boards of elections shall be responsible for operating and maintaining the equipment.

 

(c) Secure Database Maintenance.
The local boards of elections, or the Maryland State Board of Elections, shall maintain a secure database containing the photographs of registered voters taken for the purpose of issuing voter photo identification cards.

 

(d) Procedures for Issuance of Voter Photo Identification Cards.

The Maryland State Board of Elections shall adopt rules to ensure the following minimum procedures are implemented:

  1. A registered voter seeking a voter photo identification card must provide their name, date of birth, and the last four digits of their Social Security number.
  2. Voter photo identification cards shall be issued year-round, except during the period beginning at the close of early voting for a primary or general election and ending on election day.
  3. If a voter loses or damages their photo identification card, they may request a duplicate card without charge from the local board of elections. Requests may be made in person, by telephone, or by mail.
  4. If a voter’s name changes and the voter updates their voter registration to reflect the change, the voter may request a replacement card. The request may be made in person, by telephone, or by mail and requires the voter’s date of birth and the last four digits of their Social Security number.
  5. All voter photo identification cards shall include the following disclaimer:
    “Expiration of this voter photo identification card does not automatically result in the voter’s registration becoming inactive.”

Ninety (90) days prior to the expiration of a voter photo identification card, the local board of elections shall notify the voter of the impending expiration.

content.rendered:
Board of Elections Accountability & Compliance

Secure the Vote Maryland (SecureTheVoteMD) is committed to ensuring that all State and Local Boards of Elections comply with the Maryland Open Meetings Act (OMA). Transparent election administration is essential to democracy. Our mission is to restore public trust through accountability, legal compliance, and citizen empowerment.

Why the Open Meetings Act Matters

 

The OMA guarantees the public’s right to access government meetings. It’s more than a legal requirement—it’s a safeguard that strengthens confidence in election integrity. Read how election board compliance ensures accountability. 

 

Taking Action for Statewide Compliance

To protect this right, Secure the Vote Maryland filed 11 formal complaints with the Maryland Attorney General on March 24, 2025, citing OMA violations. Another 18 OMA violation formal complaints were filed on May 6th, 2025. As of 5.12.25 three formal violations of OMA were issued by the Maryland Attorney General. In response, we’ve asked the State Board of Elections:

  • What mechanisms enforce OMA compliance at the local level?
  • Do election directors receive performance-based feedback?
  • What steps are being taken to ensure uniform transparency standards?

 

Legislative Reform Underway

 

Senator Cheryl Kagan and Delegate Marc Korman have proposed legislation to strengthen OMA enforcement statewide. The bill would:

  • Expand public access to decision-making
  • Require standardized posting of meetings and minutes
  • Impose penalties for violations

 

We fully support this effort to restore transparency and trust in our election system.

 

Public Bodies, Public Responsibility

 

Election boards in all 23 counties and Baltimore City are public entities funded by taxpayers. They are not exempt from scrutiny and must operate openly and lawfully. Noncompliance with the OMA weakens public confidence. No publicly funded agency should be allowed to disregard the law.

 

Our Core Principles

 

Secure the Vote Maryland promotes:

  • Responsible use of taxpayer funds
  • Accurate, up-to-date voter rolls
  • Transparent, accessible government
  • Protection of voting rights for all eligible citizens

 

Join the Movement

 

Transparent elections are the foundation of a healthy democracy. Stand with us to demand compliance, accountability, and fairness.

👉 Get involved
👉 Speak out
👉 Help us Secure the Vote in Maryland

content.rendered:
Voter Registration List Maintenance

SecurethevoteMD is dedicated to ensuring that the State Board of Elections maintains a secure and accurate voter registration database. Accurate voter rolls are essential for fair, transparent, and trustworthy elections. As Thomas Paine wisely stated, “The right of voting for our representatives is the primary right by which all other rights are protected.”

 

Why Clean Voter Rolls Matter

Accurate voter registration lists are essential to ensuring fair, transparent, and secure elections. Without them, fraudulent or erroneous voting can compromise the voice of the people and undermine democracy.

SecurethevoteMD is committed to upholding voter integrity by demanding the Maryland State Board of Elections (SBE) follow both state and federal law in maintaining clean voter rolls.

The ERIC Problem

 

The Electronic Registration Information Center (ERIC) was founded to help states maintain clean and accurate voter rolls. But reality no longer aligns with its mission:

  • Only 19 states + DCcurrently contract with ERIC. That’s less than 60% of the country.
  • ERIC lacks access to full national voter data—how can it track duplicate or deceased votersin non-participating states?
  • Membership claims are inconsistent and outdatedacross ERIC’s own website.
  • States like Ohio, Iowa, Virginia, and Texasleft in 2023, citing lack of transparency and effectiveness.

If ERIC can’t maintain its own roster, can it be trusted with America’s voter data? Read the full report here.

 

Maryland Voter Roll Red Flags

A Maryland Voter Data Research Report reveals serious discrepancies:

  • 1,400 deceased individualsstill listed as registered voters (as of August 7, 2024).
  • Legislative audit (Oct 2023) found 327 duplicates, while independent analysis revealed over 1,021 duplicate records.
  • Additional findings include:
  • 8,455registered voters without verified mailing addresses
  • 831listing a UPS/FedEx/PO Box instead of a residential address
  • 177underage voters who cast ballots
  • 6,588 individuals who voted before they were registered

These errors far exceed the federal error threshold (1 in 125,000 ballots). In the 2022 election, that would mean no more than 16 errors — yet evidence suggests a vastly higher rate. Read the full report here.

 

Legal Obligations Ignored

 

Maryland law (Election Law §3–505) and the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 require voter roll maintenance. So why hasn’t the SBE responded to citizen concerns?

 

Despite formal submissions and repeated requests:

  • The Board has not addressedthe discrepancies
  • Public trust is eroding

 

A Call for Transparency and Action

 

We are calling on the Maryland State Board of Elections to:

  1. Immediately respondto submitted findings
  2. Publicly disclosesteps taken to remove ineligible registrations
  3. Comprehensively reviewall list maintenance procedures before the 2024 elections
  4. Hold an open sessionto answer citizen and media inquiries

Without clean rolls, we cannot trust the results. Without trust, our democracy is at risk.

content.rendered:
On March 25, 2025, President Donald J. Trump issued Executive Order 14248: “Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of American Elections.” This bold action marks a pivotal step in restoring faith in our democratic process by enhancing voter verification, securing election systems, and holding state boards accountable.

 

Read the Full Executive Order

 

Maryland Must Comply — $3.4M in Federal Funds at Stake

SecurethevoteMD is committed to ensuring that the Maryland State Board of Elections (SBE) fully complies with this Executive Order. Noncompliance could put $3,410,321 in federal election funding at risk.

Despite this, SBE Administrator Jared DeMarinis criticized the order for not addressing “misinformation” and “voter intimidation”—yet no public evidence has been presented to substantiate these claims. If such threats exist, Maryland voters deserve concrete data and a transparent report. Otherwise, the SBE’s claims risk misleading the public. Read the full article here.

Double Standards at the SBE

The SBE previously embraced President Biden’s Executive Order 14091, expanding mail-in voting and drop boxes, despite concerns over ballot chain-of-custody. But now, it claims President Trump’s Executive Order doesn’t apply because it’s not “law.”

Why the selective compliance? It’s time for the SBE to stop cherry-picking executive authority and start upholding election integrity with consistency.

 

Key Provisions of Executive Order 14248

Strengthens Election Integrity

  • Requires documentary proof of U.S. citizenship for voter registration.
  • Grants states access to federal databases (DHS, SSA, State Dept.) for verification.
  • Directs the Attorney General to prosecute non-citizen voting and election fraud.
  • Links federal election funding to state compliance.
  • Updates ballot standards to require voter-verifiable paper trails.

 

Holding States Accountable

  • States must maintain accurate voter rolls under federal law.
  • Non-compliant states face enforcement actions and loss of funding.
  • Reinforces federal law: ballots must be received by Election Day.

SecurethevoteMD is committed to holding the Maryland State Board of Elections accountable for complying with Executive Order 14248, “Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of American Elections.”

Let’s Make Elections Secure Again

“We’re going to fix our elections so that our elections are going to be honorable and honest, and people leave knowing their vote is counted.”
— President Donald J. Trump

SecurethevoteMD proudly supports this Executive Order and calls on all Marylanders to demand transparency, accountability, and integrity from those entrusted with safeguarding our democracy. Read the full Secure the Vote Maryland statement here.

Sign the Petition

NOTICE TO SIGNERS: This is a non-binding, advisory petition intended to express the will of Maryland voters to the Maryland General Assembly and other public officials. This petition is not a statutory referendum, does not invoke Article XVI of the Maryland Constitution, and does not itself enact or repeal any law.

 

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Article 13 of the Declaration of Rights of the Maryland Constitution states, “That every man (and
woman) hath a right to petition the Legislature for the redress of grievances in a peaceable and orderly manner”
(italics added, as affirmed by Article 46 of the Declaration of Rights); and
WHEREAS, the First Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees the right of the people to
petition the government for a redress of grievances; and
WHEREAS, free, fair, and transparent elections are the cornerstone of representative democracy; and
WHEREAS, Maryland voters must have confidence that elections are conducted lawfully, securely, and
uniformly, and that only eligible voters are registered and permitted to cast ballots; and
WHEREAS, the General Assembly of Maryland has considered legislation known as the Secure the Vote Act of
2026;NOW, THEREFORE, we, the undersigned residents and voters of the State of Maryland, respectfully petition
the Maryland General Assembly to enact the Secure the Vote Act of 2026, including the following provisions:

 

PETITIONED PROVISIONS
1. Repeal ballot drop box mandates, including at correctional facilities, and prohibit absentee ballot
return via drop boxes.
2. Restrict absentee voting to voters unable to vote in person for enumerated reasons and repeal
permanent absentee status.
3. Require voter identification for inperson voting, with government-issued Real I.D..
4. Require proof of U.S. citizenship for voter registration.
5. Mandate regular audits of the statewide voter registration list and public reporting of results.
6. Require signature verification and signed eligibility oaths for absentee ballots.
7. Apply uniform election standards to municipal elections, including voter registration, ID, audits, and
ballot security.
8. Prohibit nonU.S. citizens from registering or voting in municipal elections.

 

CONCLUSION
By signing below, we affirm this petition is submitted peaceably and lawfully in accordance with our
constitutional rights, and we urge the Maryland General Assembly to enact the Secure the Vote Act of 2026.

Secure YOUR Vote! A Petition for Secure Elections

Read the Petition

Dear Maryland Resident,

We are writing to invite you to stand with us in exercising our constitutional right to petition our elected officials on matters fundamental to election security and voter confidence.

NOTICE TO SIGNERS: This is a non-binding, advisory petition intended to express the will of Maryland voters to the Maryland General Assembly and other public officials. This petition is not a statutory referendum, does not invoke Article XVI of the Maryland Constitution, and does not itself enact or repeal any law.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Article 13 of the Declaration of Rights of the Maryland Constitution states, “That every man (and woman) hath a right to petition the Legislature for the redress of grievances in a peaceable and orderly manner” (italics added, as affirmed by Article 46 of the Declaration of Rights); and

WHEREAS, the First Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees the right of the people to petition the government for a redress of grievances; and

WHEREAS, free, fair, and transparent elections are the cornerstone of representative democracy; and

WHEREAS, Maryland voters must have confidence that elections are conducted lawfully, securely, and uniformly, and that only eligible voters are registered and permitted to cast ballots; and

WHEREAS, the General Assembly of Maryland has considered legislation known as the Secure the Vote Act of 2026;

NOW, THEREFORE, we, the undersigned residents and voters of the State of Maryland, respectfully petition the Maryland General Assembly to enact the Secure the Vote Act of 2026, including the following provisions:

PETITIONED PROVISIONS

<strong>Repeal ballot drop box mandates</strong>, including at correctional facilities, and prohibit absentee ballot return via drop boxes.
<strong>Restrict absentee voting</strong> to voters unable to vote in person for enumerated reasons and repeal permanent absentee status.
<strong>Require voter identification</strong> for in‑person voting, with government-issued Real I.D..
<strong>Require proof of U.S. citizenship</strong> for voter registration.
<strong>Mandate regular audits</strong> of the statewide voter registration list and public reporting of results.
<strong>Require signature verification</strong> and signed eligibility oaths for absentee ballots.
<strong>Apply uniform election standards</strong> to municipal elections, including voter registration, ID, audits, and ballot security.
<strong>Prohibit non‑U.S. citizens</strong> from registering or voting in municipal elections.

CONCLUSION

By signing below, we affirm this petition is submitted peaceably and lawfully in accordance with our constitutional rights, and we urge the Maryland General Assembly to enact the Secure the Vote Act of 2026.

%%your signature%%



In service of free, fair, and transparent elections, Maryland Citizens Petitioning for Securing YOUR Vote!

content.rendered:
The Poll Watcher's Toolkit

Citizens like you are required to keep our elections secure and accurate. You can help by being a poll worker. There are three types of poll workers.

Poll Watcher
Unofficial observer of the election process. The elections “eyes and ears.”
Apply Here
Election Judge
Official paid temporary Election Day worker. Must complete a 3-hr training through the state.
Learn More
Canvasser
Official paid, temporary Election worker who processes and counts the votes. Chosen by the local Board of Elections. Canvassing dates vary but, generally, Mail-in canvassing begins April 22nd and Provisional and Election Day ballots are counted beginning May 22nd and May 24th . Let us know if you would like to be recommended to be a Canvasser.
Request Recommendation

The Poll Watcher's Toolkit

Citizens like you are required to keep our elections secure and accurate. You can help by being a poll worker. There are three types of poll workers.

Challenger Certificate 2024 for Alex Pacheco

Observation Rights Letter

In the news

How many illegal aliens live in Maryland?

In April 2024, Maryland’s comptroller issued a “State of the Economy” brief spotlighting immigration. Despite its size, Maryland’s foreign-born population proportion tops the U.S. average (13.9% in 2022), a position the state achieved in the 2000s and has maintained...
Read More

Election watchdog group calls for review of Maryland voter registration processes

"As they were saying the state of the rolls were wonderful, the story of Ian Roberts broke, that there is in fact a non-citizen on the rolls. Something they have said over and over again does not happen," said Kate Sullivan, the director of Secure the Vote...
Read More

Maryland Republican lawmakers demand review of voter rolls after former Baltimore principal is arrested by ICE

Maryland Republican lawmakers are demanding answers after a former Baltimore principal, now found to be in the country illegally, was registered to vote...
Read More

Illegal registered to vote just ‘tip of the iceberg,’ says GOP delegate

Maryland state Delegate Lauren Arikan blasted Democratic leaders in her state after an illegal alien was found registered to vote, saying this is “the tip of the iceberg.”...
Read More

Maryland’s Dirty Voter
Rolls

Republicans Sound the Alarm as Feds Join Scrutiny

In a state where Democrats have long held political dominance, Maryland’s elections officials are facing intensifying scrutiny over what many see as systemic failures in maintaining voter integrity...
Read More

Election Integrity
Victory!

Federal Judge Upholds the Right to Inspect Maryland Voter Rolls

Maryland is finally learning what other states have learned: federal law requires transparency in the voting process.
District Court Judge Matthew J. Maddox of the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland...
Read More

Victory for Election Integrity: Maryland Court Rules Against State Overreach in Landmark Voter Rights Case

The United States District Court for the District of Maryland struck a blow for election integrity by siding with plaintiffs Katherine Strauch Sullivan and David Morsberger in their legal battle against Maryland State Board of Elections officials.
Read More

Supporting democracy means fighting for secure elections | GUEST COMMENTARY

Nov. 5 marked a resounding victory for Donald Trump and his wing of the Republican Party. However, while the presidential race is over, the work to prove our elections are valid and lawful must continue.
Read More

Poll workers are in high demand – especially Maryland Republicans

As local election boards work around the clock to recruit and train workers before early voting starts next week, some Maryland counties are facing pressure to hire more Republican election judges.
Read More

What’s Going on with Maryland’s Election Integrity? Asks Mike Lindell

“We have great people in Maryland working toward election accuracy,” said Kate Sullivan who was interviewed by Mike Lindell (co-hosting for the War Room). Kate Sullivan is the Team Leader for Secure the Vote Maryland and Maryland Election Integrity, LLC.
Read More

A group plans to challenge election boards nationwide

A group questioning the validity of state voting systems and election procedures across the country is asking a federal court to rule Maryland’s election board is out of compliance with state and federal elections laws.
Read More

MD Legislators To Vote On Bill That Puts BOE in Charge of Election Disinformation

According to a March 7 recorded Zoom call, Maryland State Board of Elections (MDSBE) Director Jared DeMarinis and several state legislators believe the bill is specific enough to avoid infringement of First Amendment speech. However, others are not so sure.
Read More

Maryland State Board of Elections sued for inaccurate voting records

A group of everyday Maryland voters, that also happens to include computer scientists and statisticians, combed through the last three years of data from the Maryland State Board of Elections They were alarmed by what they found.
Read More

Frivolous Lawsuit Targets Maryland’s Voter Rolls and Voting Systems

In Maryland, two election denial groups are exploiting the courts to help lay the groundwork to undermine the 2024 election. The effort, part of a string of challenges to voter rolls and election procedures by an expansive network of activists and organizations.
Read More

Group whose chairman challenged 2020 presidential vote count sues Maryland elections board

United Sovereign Americans, a nonprofit Missouri corporation, says the Maryland State Board of Elections’ rolls contain thousands of voters of questionable status, including some with no certified address and others who died or moved away.
Read More

Challenging Election Irregularities in Maryland

United Sovereign Americans, a nationwide group dedicated to fair and honest elections, has joined with Maryland Election Integrity, LLC, in filing a lawsuit in Maryland Federal Court against the Maryland State Board of Elections with Judge Stephanie A. Gallagher presiding.
Read More

Right-Wing Groups File New Election Lawsuit in Maryland

The plaintiffs allege that the Maryland Board of Elections has failed to keep accurate voter rolls, improperly uses voting machines that are not certified correctly and unlawfully denied public information requests. Specifically, the lawsuit claims that Maryland’s voter rolls are “not accurate and current” in violation of the National Voter Registration Act.
Read More

The Sad State of Maryland's Voter Rolls: 79k+ Inaccurate Records Found

After three years of grueling work, a group of citizen volunteers in Maryland, led by Kate Sullivan and David Morsberger, completed their report containing a statewide canvass and the results of their meticulous investigation of the state's voter rolls.
Read More

content.rendered:
Lawsuit Document

On March 5th, 2024, Maryland Election Integrity LLC and United Sovereign Americans, Inc. brought a Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief against the Maryland State Board of Elections (hereinafter referred to as MDSBE). The two groups are seeking to hold the MDSBE accountable for the apparent deficient Maryland State Voter Registration Database, improper certification of voting machines, and noncompliance with the Public Information Act (PIA). The plaintiffs primary purpose for filing the lawsuit is to force these identified issues to be addressed and remedied in advance of the 2024 election.

content.rendered:
JOIN US FOR SECURE THE VOTE ACT 2026 LOBBY DAY — WED FEB 4 AT 9AM — CLICK HERE TO REGISTER!
Strengthening our Constitutional Republic through secure voting
Citizens must be able to have trust that their elections are secure and accurate for the persistence of democratic institutions.
Discover more
Trump Executive Order
If Maryland fails to comply with the Order, it could face serious financial repercussions. Non-compliance may result in the loss of up to $3.2 million in federal funding. At stake is not just money, but public trust in the integrity of Maryland’s elections.
Discover more
Election Board Accountability
How to keep your Election Board Accountable? As stewards of our democratic process, Election Boards have a duty to uphold transparency and compliance. At stake is the public trust in Maryland’s elections.
Discover more
List Maintenance
A Maryland Data Research Report, included a review of 1400 deceased individuals listed on the official Voter Registration Database in August 2024. Why this is important?
Discover more

Strengthening our Democratic Republic through secure voting

Citizens must be able to have trust that their elections are secure and accurate for the persistence of democratic institutions.

Discover more

Statement of Purpose

Secure the Vote Maryland aims to restore faith in Maryland Elections through voter accuracy.
We are a team of dedicated Maryland citizens who have organized various efforts to verify voter
validity and ensure the integrity of our official Maryland voter database.

The Mission of Secure the Vote Maryland

Secure the Vote Maryland is dedicated to protecting the citizens of Maryland by assuring transparent, lawful, and trustworthy elections. Our goal is to restore faith in our elections by identifying vulnerabilities in our election system, focusing on election integrity, voter integrity, voter accuracy, and voter validity. We work to hold the Board of Election Officials accountable to their affirmative duty to maintain accurate voter rolls. Our tireless efforts have yielded evidence which demands remedies including updating, fixing, and eliminating processes that created these vulnerabilities we have identified. Our goal is to hold the State Board of Elections accountable to remedying these vulnerabilities in the system in advance of the 2026 Primary and General Election.

The right of citizens to freely choose our representatives guarantees that our government upholds our will and serves by consent. Our life, liberty, and pursuit of happiness are secured by the law. Secure the Vote Maryland is particularly committed to ensuring fidelity to the law as it relates to elections and voting. Secure the Vote Maryland is ready to guard the validity of elections through public outreach, education, and litigation.

Did You Sign the Petition to urge Maryland General Assembly to enact meaningful reforms to safeguard our election process?

Read More
who we are
Our Secure the Vote team includes citizen volunteers working locally with Maryland Election Integrity LLC and nationally with United Sovereign Americans to ensure valid, accurate, and trustworthy voter rolls. Team members vary from data and legal experts to at-home moms and retired citizens.
We work with the local board of elections to assist in their oversight of the voter rolls. Clean voter rolls are required under the law for the voters to trust the election system. When we identify critical system irregularities, lack of controls, and voter data errors, the board of elections, by law, must remedy the concerns of the citizens.
Our team members also coordinate with the Maryland Voter Integrity Group and the Election Integrity Network (home of the Elections Bill of Rights).  The overall mission is ensure that election laws guarantee accuracy and reflect the will of the voters and that the elections are conducted in accordance with applicable law without favor to any party, candidate, voter or group of voters.

Accountability

Trump’s Executive Order Voter Roll Maintenance, Board of Elections Compliance

Legislation

Voter ID, Signature Verification, Voter Bill of Rights

Advocacy

Election Accuracy Day of Action, Testimonies , Petition , Expert Guidance , Citizen Action

articles

Your Source to Stay informed

Citizens all over the state are working hard in many different ways to secure our elections.  This is your resource to stay up-to-date on our efforts to secure our elections.

View more

Unofficial observer of the election process. The elections “eyes and ears.”

Election Judge

Official paid temporary Election Day worker. Must complete a 3-hr training through the state.

Canvasser

Official paid, temporary Election worker who processes and counts the votes.

Closer

Reliable and consistent practices in voting and counting foster enduring trust in election results.
